    • HIV & AIDS
    • Epidemiology
    • EPIDEMIOLOGIC STUDIES

    STRENGTHS AND LIMITATIONS OF THIS STUDY

    • The analyses in our study were not based on individual-level characteristics as in previous studies. Given that the use of condoms is negotiated between partners, we explored sexual behaviours based on self-reports from both sides of couples and assessed the factors associated with condom use at the couple level.

    • The sample size for the analysis on correlates of condom use was relatively small; a larger sample size would be more convincing.

    • The sexual behaviours surveyed in this study were not sufficiently specific. Learning more about the characteristics of extramarital sexual partners could help develop targeted measures to prevent HIV transmission to other populations.

    Introduction

    Sexual contact is now the predominant route for HIV transmission in China, with 73.7% and 23.0% of newly diagnosed people living with HIV (PLWH) infected via heterosexual and homosexual transmission in 2019, respectively.1 HIV-discordant couples, defined as one HIV positive and the other HIV negative, account for approximately 25% of heterosexual HIV transmission in China.2 HIV-negative spouses have become a high-risk population for HIV infection owing to frequent unprotected sexual intercourse with their seropositive partners.3 In sub-Saharan Africa, more than 80% of new HIV infections in women were estimated to be acquired from their married or long-term partners.4 As HIV transmission within discordant couples significantly contributes to the overall infection burden, it is necessary to better understand the extent and context of sexual risk behaviours among these couples.

    The lack of condom use is a direct cause of HIV transmission within discordant couples.3 A meta-analysis of HIV risk among heterosexual couples suggested a per-act transmission probability of 0.08% for unprotected sex.5 Modest HIV infection probabilities per sex act will translate into substantial cumulative risks over time.6 In addition to being an independent predictor, inconsistent condom use has also been shown to compromise the effectiveness of other measures.7 He et al conducted a cohort study and found that in couples in which HIV-positive partners were receiving antiretroviral therapy (ART), the incidence of HIV in couples without consistent condom use was higher than that in couples with consistent condom use.7 Despite the significant effects of ART in reducing the probability of infection in HIV-negative spouses,8 it could also be affected by other factors such as the compliance of HIV-positive individuals with ART. Therefore, it is important to avoid unprotected sexual exposure completely in such cases. A recent report stated that consistent condom use plus the provision of timely ART to HIV-positive index spouses is the most efficient strategy for preventing HIV secondary transmission between HIV-discordant couples.9 However, the prevalence of consistent condom use among HIV-discordant spouses is still low.10 11

    Previous studies on condom use among HIV-discordant couples have mainly focused on characteristics at the individual level, and some have drawn conclusions based only on self-reports from one side of the couple.12 13 However, condom use is usually the result of negotiations between partners. Therefore, it is necessary to explore related factors at the couple level to gain a better understanding of condom use among HIV-discordant couples. In this study, we investigated the characteristics of sexual behaviours among HIV-discordant heterosexual couples in Anhui Province, China, and assessed the correlates of condom use at the couple level to provide a basis for interventions in HIV transmission.

    Methods

    Study site and participants

    This study was conducted from June 2018 to June 2019 in seven prefectures along the Yangtze River in Anhui Province, China, where there is a relatively dense urban population and leading socioeconomic development, public service systems and facility construction.

    Eligible participants were married couples confirmed to have HIV discordance, at least 18 years of age and willing to participate in the study. All participants provided their informed consent. Those who were unable to complete the questionnaire owing to mental illness or other reasons were excluded.

    Patient and public involvement

    Patients and/or the public were not involved in the design, or conduct, or reporting, or dissemination plans of this research.

    Sampling size

    The focus of the study was on condom use and the associated risk factors in HIV-discordant couples. Thus, the sample size necessary for this cross-sectional study was computed using a single population proportion formula by considering the following assumptions: the proportion of consistent condom use (approximately 50%) in HIV-discordant couples in China,10 14 a 95% confidence level, a 10% margin of error and a 20% non-response rate.

    where n is the minimum sample size, Zα/2 is the critical value of the desired level of confidence 95% (1.96), p is the proportion of consistent condom use in HIV-discordant couples in China and d is the margin of error (10%). For an estimated non-response rate of 20%, the planned sample size was 122 couples (97/0.8). Finally, of the 206 couples included in the study, 130 couples had marital sex in the past 6 months; that is, they reported information regarding condom use. The response rate was 94.9% (206 of 217). Missing values were imputed using the corresponding available information from spouses or return visits.

    Data collection

    Sociodemographics, sexual behaviours in the past 6 months, and other information such as knowledge, spousal notification, and support and care were collected individually from the participants using a structured questionnaire. Each couple was interviewed separately and simultaneously in separate rooms. Trained health workers conducted face-to-face interviews. The use of condoms was classified as always (using condoms during each sexual act), sometimes or never. Specifically, couples in which both partners independently reported 100% condom use were classified into the ‘always’ group. If at least one of the partners replied 0% condom use, they were considered to be in the ‘never’ group, and all the others were in the ‘sometimes’ group. In addition, regarding the questions ‘Have you had sexual contact with your spouse in the last 6 months?’ and ‘Frequency of marital sexual contact in the last 6 months’, the answers from the HIV-positive participants were used for subsequent analyses.

    The data were entered into EpiData V.3.1 and audited for accuracy, then transferred to the SPSS v.26 database for further management. Descriptive statistics of sociodemographics, HIV knowledge and extramarital sex among HIV-positive individuals and their negative partners were summarised. Frequency and percentage were used as categorical variables, with the mean and SD for continuous variables (eg, age). Differences among variables were tested using the Χ2 test or Fisher’s exact test for categorical data and t-test for continuous data. The reliability of self-reported marital sex among couples was assessed using the kappa statistic (measuring inter-rater agreement for categorical items) by matching the responses of HIV-positive participants to their partners’ responses to the same question. In bivariate analyses, Kruskal-Wallis tests were used to assess the differences in condom use between different subgroups, and the Spearman rank correlation coefficient test was used to assess the relationship between condom use and marital duration. Variables with p values less than 0.1 in the bivariate analyses were used as candidates for stepwise ordinal logistic regression modelling. ORs and the corresponding 95% CIs were calculated and used to determine whether a variable was independently associated with condom use. P values of less than 0.05 were statistically significant. All analyses were performed using Stata (V.17.0).

    Statistical analysis

    Results

    Sociodemographics, HIV knowledge and extramarital sex of participants

    Overall, 206 HIV-discordant couples participated in this study, of whom 79.1% HIV-positive respondents were male (table 1). The mean age of the participants was 42.0 (SD=10.1) years, ranging from 19.0 to 75.0 years. HIV-positive participants had a higher education level than the HIV-negative spouses (p=0.007). More HIV-positive individuals agreed that proper condom use could reduce HIV sexual transmission (p=0.043). A difference in extramarital sex between spouses was also observed, with a higher incidence among HIV-positive respondents than among HIV-negative respondents (p=0.015).

    View this table:
    • View inline
    • View popup
    Table 1

    Sociodemographics, HIV knowledge and extramarital sex of the HIV-positive participants and their negative spouses

    Marital sex and condom use and associated factors

    We explored marital sexual behaviours and conducted corresponding reliability assessments among couples. The results indicated a high level of agreement in having had sexual intercourse with their spouse in the past 6 months (kappa=0.906) and condom use (kappa=0.871) (table 2). A moderate agreement was observed regarding the frequency of marital sexual contact (kappa=0.719). After grouping couples based on their responses to sexual behaviours, 63.1% (130 of 206) of couples had marital sex in the past 6 months, of which 89.2% (116 of 130), 4.6% (6 of 130) and 6.2% (8 of 130) always, sometimes and never used condoms during sex, respectively.

    View this table:
    • View inline
    • View popup
    Table 2

    Concordance and discordance in self-reports of marital sex in the past 6 months between HIV-positive participants and their negative partners

    In bivariate analyses, variables significantly associated with condom use among HIV-discordant couples were marital duration (p<0.001), ways of spousal notification (p=0.021), the HIV-negative spouse’s support and care for the infected (p=0.007), having any children or not (p=0.050), marital status (p<0.001) and awareness of condoms preventing HIV sexual transmission (p=0.038) (table 3).

    View this table:
    • View inline
    • View popup
    Table 3

    Factors at couple level related to condom use among HIV-discordant couples: bivariate analyses

    Multivariate analysis indicated that marital duration, the HIV-negative spouse’s support and care for the infected, and marital status were independent predictors of condom use among HIV-discordant couples (table 4). For every additional year of marital duration, the probability of condom use increased by 15% (OR=1.15; 95% CI: 1.03, 1.28). The lack of support and care within a couple was linked to less use of condoms compared with couples in which the HIV-negative spouse usually gave support and care to the infected (OR=0.25; 95% CI: 0.07, 0.94). Furthermore, remarried couples were less likely to use condoms than those who were in their first marriage (OR=0.08; 95% CI: 0.02, 0.43).

    View this table:
    • View inline
    • View popup
    Table 4

    Factors at couple level related to condom use among HIV-discordant couples: multivariate analysis

    Discussion

    Consistent condom use remains a critical component of a comprehensive and sustainable approach to preventing HIV transmission in sexually active, HIV-discordant couples. Understanding the sexual behaviours in this population and identifying particular high-risk subgroups for low condom use are essential for further targeted interventions. In this study, various key findings were obtained. First, an unexpectedly high prevalence of consistent condom use was observed in HIV-discordant couples. Second, marital duration, the HIV-negative spouse’s support and care for the infected, and marital status were independent factors of condom use at the couple level. Third, HIV-positive individuals had a higher incidence of extramarital sex than HIV-negative individuals.

    The frequency of consistent condom use in this study was higher than that reported in similar studies conducted in China10 15 and other countries.13 16 This could have been owing to the high level of HIV knowledge and awareness of partners’ infection status, both of which are related to less-risky sexual behaviours.12 17 18 In the current study, we believe that a substantial share of the self-reported sexual behaviour was valid due to the high level of agreement in responses between couples, although reporting bias might exist in a large number of surveys about sexual behaviours. The involvement of couples ensured the reliability of the self-reports to some extent.19

    This study quantified the impact of marital duration on condom use. We found that the probability of condom use increased by 15% for every additional year of marital duration. With the amount of time living together increasing, couples become more trusting and supportive of each other, leading to a consistent decision regarding condom use. Previous studies have reported that couples with shorter marriage duration had a higher risk of HIV infection among HIV-negative spouses.20 Whether condom use is an intermediary factor in this relationship warrants further study.

    Consistent with other studies,11 21 lack of care and support between spouses was a negative predictor of condom use. According to the literature, couples in which both partners understood and cared for each other were more likely to reach a consensus on condom use and engage in less-risky sexual behaviours.22 23 Stable couples in higher-quality relationships may no longer need to repeatedly discuss condom use, as it has become an established practice. Other studies reported different findings, showing a correlation between intimacy in a relationship and less frequent condom use.24 25 However, most participants in these studies were men who had sex with men, and they believed that condoms could reduce pleasure and negatively affect intimacy. In discordant couples, HIV-positive individuals may lean toward using condoms to protect their emotionally intimate partners. Future work is needed to explore effective measures to balance intimacy and risk-reduction motives.

    The present study also revealed that remarried couples were less likely to use condoms than those who were in their first marriage. This difference may be because people who have experienced divorce are more likely to break through the restraints of sexual behaviour.26 Another possible explanation is that, in this study, the rate (62.5%) of ‘awareness of condoms preventing HIV sexual transmission’ among HIV-negative spouses was lower in remarried couples than in first-married couples (95.9%) (p=0.008), which potentially increased unprotected sex. To date, few studies have been conducted on the relationship between remarriage and condom use in discordant couples; however, the association between remarriage and a high prevalence of HIV has been extensively explored.20 27 Interventions to increase awareness of infection risk and condom use are highly needed in this group.

    Extramarital sex and concurrent sexual relationships have been increasing in recent years,28 which not only increase the possibility of HIV transmission to the general population but also potentially increase the risk of HIV infection in HIV-negative spouses. Individuals with multiple sexual partners are susceptible to sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), and the coexistence of HIV and STDs increases the risk of HIV transmission between couples.29 30 In general, a low prevalence of extramarital sex was observed in this study, which may be attributed to social desirability and reporting bias. Nevertheless, the difference in extramarital sex between HIV-positive and HIV-negative spouses should be considered. Experiencing HIV-related stigma might lead to anxiety and unsafe sexual behaviour among PLWH, including more partners and a higher likelihood of having extramarital relations.31 The prevalence of extramarital sex among infected people has also been linked to a strong sense of responsibility to protect their families from infection.32 In China, interventions for PLWH mainly target HIV-discordant couples, and they may not fully cover the range of possible sexual relationships with PLWH. Certain precautions must be taken to protect the commercial and casual partners of PLWH and reduce the spread of HIV.

    Our study has some limitations. First, the number of couples who reported inconsistent condom use was relatively small; a larger sample size would increase the statistical power and be more convincing in future studies. Second, the sexual behaviours surveyed in this study were not sufficiently specific. Understanding the frequency of extramarital sex and learning more about the characteristics of extramarital sexual partners, such as their occupations and relationships with respondents, could help develop targeted measures to prevent HIV transmission to other populations. Third, combining a quantitative study with a qualitative one that directly investigates the exact reasons for not using condoms may be more useful in identifying the associated factors.

    In conclusion, the current study provides additional information concerning issues of marital and extramarital sex among married HIV-discordant couples. The extramarital sex of HIV-positive spouses warrants attention. Additionally, we found that factors affecting condom use at the couple level related to marital intimacy and stability, including shorter marital duration, lack of support and care and remarriage, were associated with lower condom use among HIV-discordant couples. Implementation of interventions, such as increasing support and care between spouses to promote marital intimacy and stability, could reduce unprotected sexual behaviour.

    Ethics approval

All participants provided written informed consent. Individual data were promised confidentiality, and all participants received free testing, consultations and evaluations after the survey.
